entry.title: Sinusoidal channel
entry.content: This is a comparison between 1st order and 2nd order time integration for a Taylor air bubble flowing thru a sinusoidal channel. It can be seen the difference of bubble shape for the same simulation time between both temporal approaches. We conclude that the time discretization may change the bubble shape, therefore changing the numerical result.

entry.title: Rayleigh Taylor instability
entry.content: A case with strong interface deformation is investigated. It is described by the unstable situation of a heavy fluid resting upon a lighter one in a gravitational field. The density ratio of the fluids is 0.1383 and their viscosities are equal. This case is two-dimensional and no surface tension acts on the interface. A rectangular domain of dimensions 1x4 was used. The interface is initialized with a sinusoidal perturbation of amplitude A=0.05. Symmetry boundary conditions were used on all domain boundaries. The non-dimensional numbers are Re = 391.37 and Fr = 0.31928. The same conditions were simulated by Lopez et al. (2005) using an interface capturing method and by Popinet and Zaleski (1999) using a front tracking algorithm. The present results for the shape of the interface are displayed in fig. (3). The instability develops a typical mushroom shape. At larger times, thin filaments are generated which are clearly resolved by the mesh.

entry.title: Three rising bubble test cases
entry.content: The figure shows bubble shape transition of the rising air bubble immersed in sugar water solution. The numerical results were compared to the widely cited experiments performed by Bhaga and Weber (1981). From left to right, the viscosity of the liquid solution (dark brown color) increases and thus the bubble shape changes. The left hand side figure presents a smooth shape bubble (light brown color) while the right hand side figure presents edges at the bubble corners. It is possible to conclude that the viscosity of the liquid has strong effect on the bubble shape.

entry.title: Break up in sinusoidal Channel
entry.content: Break-up of bubble in two-phase flow thought a sinusoidal channel. The figure shows the pressure field of a taylor bubble about to break the interface up. The colors represent the scale of pressure along the bubble length, where the red color stands for higher pressure, while the blue one represents low pressure. The non-dimensional pressure scale can be seen in the figure bar. After the break-up, the bubble eventually would split in two bubbles and the their dynamics would be different of the single bubble, since the volume of each bubble are different if compared to the original one.

entry.title: Taylor Bubble
entry.content: Two-phase flow thought a microchannel. The figure shows the taylor bubble flowing along the microchannel. It can be seen that the tail of the bubble has a particular shape due to its motion. Morevover, the surface mesh is non-uniform, i.e. in the tail is more refined due to the strong deformation of this type of flow condition, and the nose of the bubble is smooth and higher tringles can be used instead, saving computational time.

entry.title: Sinusoidal Channel
entry.content: Two-phase flow thought a sinusoidal channel. The figure shows the last stage of the mesh manufacturing. It can be seen two distinct structures: the channel and bubble’s meshes. The simulation is therefore performed and results on the bubble flow dynamics is achived.

entry.title: Rising Bubble
entry.content: Visualization of surface (triangles) and background (tetrahedrons) meshes for two-phase flows simulation of an air bubble in a water-sugar solution using an 3D Finite Element Arbitrary Lagrangian Eulerian code. As can be seen, the background mesh is more refined below the air bubble, where fluid recirculation is stronger, and the surface mesh presents a constant edge lengh along its shape.

entry.title: 3D Vortex
entry.content: The surface mesh is represented by interconnected triangular faces in which a fully 3D vortex field distorts it. The surface mesh is initially configured as a sphere and later assumes such a form. The field is then reversed to recover the initial sphere shape. The snapshot presented here was taken in its strongest deformation. The surface mesh colored by the magnitude of the vortex field velocity. The red color represents high velocity, while the blue one stands for low intensity.

entry.title: Single Vortex
entry.content: Two-phase flow on a single vortex background flow. This benchmark is an important tool to test the limits of the interface reconstruction.The tetrahedral background mesh is colored by the magnitude of the vortex field velocity. The red color represents high velocity, while the blue one stands for low intensity.

entry.title: Sessile Drop
entry.content: Comparison between numerical solution of an axisymmetric sessile drop and the exact solution of its shape derived by the Young-Laplace equation of capillarity.

entry.title: Rotating Disk
entry.content: Single phase rotating disk flow. The boundary layer is shown decomposed onto three orthogonal directions: x, y and z. The inflow comes from the top while the outlow is set by the movement of the circular disk, where the fluid is thrown out when approaches the plate.
